editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: AN ANSWER TO THE DESERTION DISCUSS'D.
div.p:
IF many of our Long-Rob'd Divines, puft up with a Conceit of their own Parts, would but keep clo≈øer to their Texts, and their Duties, mo≈øt certainly our Peace and Union would be much firmer, and more a≈ø≈øured then it is. For being ≈øway'd by Intere≈øt and Profit, they are more afraid of lo≈øing the Advantages of Earthly Preferment, then the Trea≈øures of Heavenly Felicity. Unle≈øs they ≈øwim in their own Wi≈øhes and De≈øires, all Things are out of Order. The Church is in danger, they cry; here are Sharers coming in among Us: And by an odd kind of Eccle≈øia≈øtical Policy, ≈øeem rather inclinable to return under the Yoke of Popery, then to endure the Equality of a Di≈ø≈øenting Prote≈øtant; rather to be at the check of a Pope's Nuncio, then ≈øuffer the Fraternity of a Prote≈øtant Nonconformi≈øt. They ≈øaid nothing to the late King, till he began to touch their Copy-holds: then they call'd out for Help; and now they are angry with their Relief, becau≈øe they are afraid of well they know not what. And this is their Misfortune, that if all things an≈øwer not the full Height of their Expectations, they are the fir≈øt that ≈øhould be la≈øt di≈ø≈øatisfied. If all things go not well, as they imagine, they
pre≈øently grow moody and wa≈øpi≈øh; and while they in≈øinuate their empty Notions into others, who admiring the fluency of their Pulpit Language, either out of Ignorance, or Lazine≈øs, allow them a Prerogative over their Under≈øtandings, the whole Nation mu≈øt be embroyl'd by their Surmi≈øes and Mi≈øtru≈øts.

El≈øe what had that Gentleman, who wrote the De≈øertion Di≈øcu≈øs'd, to do to bu≈øy his Brains with a Subject, neither appertaining to his Function, nor proper for his Talent? Why ≈øhould ‚Ä¢ e be ≈øetting him≈øelf up again≈øt the voted Judgment of the chiefe≈øt and greate≈øt part of the Kingdom? A Man of his Profe≈ø≈øion would have doubtle≈øs better employ'd him≈øelf, in contemplating the Story of the Three Murmurers again≈øt Mo≈øes; and there have learn'd a more ≈øanctifi'd Le≈ø≈øon, then to exalt his Soph ‚Ä¢ ≈øtry again≈øt the Debates of a Solemn A≈ø≈øembly contriving the Publick ‚Ä¢ re≈øervation. For certainly never was a fairer Pro≈øpect then now, ≈øince the many Revolutions under which the Briti≈øh Monarchy has labour'd, of its being re≈øtor'd to its ancient Grandeur and Renown, and of enjoying the Advantages of Peace and Pro≈øperity in a higher mea≈øure then ever. So that it mu≈øt be look'd upon as the Effect, either of a mo≈øt pernicious Malice, or a ≈øtrange di≈øtraction of Brain, for ≈øuch Di≈øcu≈ø≈øers as the≈øe, to be throwing about the Darnel of their nice and froward Conceptions, on purpo≈øe to choak the Expectations of ≈øo glorious a Harve≈øt. For they mu≈øt be Men that want the government of right Rea≈øon within them≈øelves, as being en≈ølav'd either to vicious Cu≈øtom, or partial Affection, or el≈øe they would never run them≈øelves and others with ≈øo much precipitancy, into the ≈øhame and ignominy of upholding the ≈øubvertors of National Con≈øtitutions. And all this to blacken and defame the noble Endeavours, and prudent Coun≈øels of tho≈øe renowned Patriots that pur≈øu'd the only means to re≈øcue a langui≈øhing Monarchy from impending Thraldom and Ruin.

He does not wonder, he ≈øays, that a Man of ≈øo much ≈øen≈øe and integrity as his Friend is, ≈øhould be ≈øurprized at the Thrones being declared Vacant by the Lower Hou≈øe of Convention. For how, ≈øays his Friend, can the Seat of the Government be empty, while the King, who all grant, had an unque≈øtionable Title, is ≈øtill living.

But the Di≈øcu≈ø≈øer here forgot, that it had been the re≈øolv'd
Opinion of two Parliaments already, That there was no Security for the Prote≈øtant Religion, the King's Life, or the e≈øtabli≈øh'd Government of the Kingdom, without pa≈ø≈øing a Bill for di≈øabling the Duke of York to inherit the Imperial Crown of England and Ireland; and that unle≈øs a Bill were pa≈øs'd for excluding the Duke of York, the Hou≈øe could not give any Supply to the King, without Danger to his per≈øon, the Hazard of the Prote≈øtant Religion, and Breach of the Tru≈øt in them repos'd by the People. Upon which a Bill did pa≈øs the Commons, and was ≈øent up to the Lords for their Concurrence, by which James Duke of York was excluded and made for ever uncapable to Inherit, Po≈ø≈øe≈øs or Enjoy the Imperial Crown of this Realm, &c. and he adjudg'd Guilty of High Trea≈øon, and to ≈øuffer the Pains and Penalties as in Ca≈øe of High Trea≈øon, if after ≈øuch a Time he ≈øhould claim, challenge, or attempt to po≈ø≈øe≈øs or exerci≈øe any Authority or Juri≈ødiction, as King, &c. in any of the ≈øaid Dominions. 'Tis true, the Lords did not pa≈øs this Bill, for Rea≈øons well known; yet was it ≈øuch a mutilation to the Duke's Title, to be di≈øabled from ≈øucceeding in the Kingdom, by the whole Body of the Commons, who are the Repre≈øentatives of the Nation, that it can never be ≈øaid, that all Men granted his Title unque≈øtionable, as the Di≈øcu≈ø≈øer impo≈øes upon the World. Be≈øides the many In≈øtances in Hi≈øtory, of ≈øeveral Princes who have forfeited their Succe≈ø≈øion, and con≈øequently their Title to the Crown, for revolting from the E≈øtabli≈øh'd Religion of the Realm.

But, ≈øays the Di≈øcu≈ø≈øer, for I look upon his Friend and Him to be all one; (and that he does but put the Que≈øtion with one ≈øide of his Mouth, and an≈øwer it with the other) I had thought our Laws, as well as our Religion, had been again≈øt the Depo≈øing Doctrine.

That's not the Que≈øtion; but whether a Prince may commit tho≈øe Mi≈øcarriages in Government, whether he may not ≈øo far, peccare in Leges & Rempublicam, as to incur the Forfeiture of his Regal Power? and whether a Prince may be allow'd to ≈øubvert the ancient Con≈øtitutions and Religion of a Nation, and yet be ≈øaid to be the Lawful King of that Realm? The≈øe are the Que≈øtions: For then it is not the Law that depo≈øes him, nor the Religion that ju≈øtifies it. But it is He that depo≈øes Him≈øelf: 'tis the bad Advice
of Evil Coun≈øellors to which he Li≈øtens, and which he follows to the ruin of the Kingdom, contrary to the Original Contract between Princes and People, grounded upon the Foundations of all Original Government; I ≈øay, 'tis that Adhering to Evil Coun≈øel which depo≈øes a Prince by degrading him from a Lawful King to an Unlawful Tyrant, and renders him Liable to the Animadver≈øion of the Law, and the impeachments of the oppre≈øs'd and injur'd People. To a≈ø≈øert otherwi≈øe were to deprive all National Law and Religion of their ≈øelf Defence; which is again≈øt all the Law and Religion in the World. I am apt to believe that Chri≈øt him≈øelf had no very good Opinion of the lawfulne≈øs of Herod's Regality, when he ≈øent him that Me≈ø≈øage, Go tell that Fox, Herod: Which I look upon as a Depo≈øal and Degrading of that Arbitrary Prince by the Founder of our Religion, in his own Brea≈øt and Judgment, though he forbore the Execution of his Cele≈øtial Power. And therefore it is not the Error of Religion, but the Fault of tho≈øe that do not well di≈øtingui≈øh, that Religion ≈øuffers in her Doctrines. For only he who governs according to Law is a King, he that endeavours to ≈øubvert the Law, is none. Nor is every rambling and precipitate Brain to be Judg of this neither, but the Solid Law, and fundamental Con≈øtitutions of the Realm. So that the Country Gentleman was mi≈øtaken in his Thoughts, both of our Laws and our Religion. However the pretended Scrupulous Country Gentleman de≈øires the Di≈øcu≈ø≈øer to expound the State-Riddle of the Vacancy; and to give him the Ground of the late extraordinary Revolution.

To which the Di≈øcu≈ø≈øer gives no direct an≈øwer at pre≈øent, but de≈øires his Friend to take notice, That the Gentlemen of the Convention, who declar'd a Vacancy in the Government, lay'd the main Stre≈øs of their opinion upon the King's withdrawing him≈øelf. For that ≈øince the Story of the French League, and the Bu≈øine≈øs of the Prince of Wales were pa≈øs'd over in ≈øilence, mo≈øt Men believed that the pretended Breach of that which they called the Original Contract was no more then a popular Flouri≈øh.

All which is ≈øuch an imperfect peice of Incoherence, that none but a madman would have thru≈øt in by Head and Shoulders, as the Di≈øcu≈ø≈øer has done. For how can it be inferr'd that the Breach of the Original Contract, ≈øhould be a Popular
Flouri≈øh, becau≈øe the Clande≈øtin League, and the Fal≈øe Birth are hitherto pa≈øs'd over in ≈øilence? As for the ≈øurreptitious Birth, one would think it was ≈øufficiently dilated upon in the Declaration of the Lords; and why it is not farther brought upon the Stage, there may be ≈øeveral Rea≈øons given; and among the re≈øt, becau≈øe it may be thought that the Impo≈øture will vani≈øh of it ≈øelf, and ≈øo there will be no need of ca≈øting an Eternal Blot upon the memory of them that contriv'd and own'd it. Then for the Clande≈øtin League, it Suffices that there is apparent Proof of it in Bank. But to call the Breach of the Original Contract pretended, and a Popular Flouri≈øh, is a yerk of Malitious Reflection, which only ≈øerves to expo≈øe the Di≈øcu≈ø≈øer to Publick cen≈øure. For as there is nothing more certain, then that there is an Original Contract between the King and People of England, the Breach of which has co≈øt the Effu≈øion of ≈øo much Blood; ≈øo is it as certain that that Original Contract was never ≈øo infallibly broken then it was of late. Which as it is allow'd by all the Laws of God and Man, to be a ≈øufficient ground to ≈øeek a Remedy; ≈øo was nothing more vigorou≈øly urg'd by the Convention. Which might have convinc'd the Di≈øcu≈ø≈øer, that they did not pretend it for a popular Flouri≈øh.

But now, le≈øt the Country Gentleman ≈øhould be ≈øhogg'd by ≈øeeing the Votes of ≈øo con≈øiderable a Meeting, debated by a private Hand; the Di≈øcu≈ø≈øer reminds him, That a Parliament and a Convention are two different Things. The latter, for want of the King's Writs and Concurrence, having no ≈øhare in the Legi≈ølative Power.

But the Di≈øcu≈ø≈øer forgets, that it was only a Convention of Lords that ≈øent to Richard the Second to meet them at We≈øtmin≈øter; which the King at fir≈øt promis'd to do; but upon altering his Mind, ≈øent him another peremptory Me≈ø≈øage, that if he would not come according to his Promi≈øe, they would chu≈øe another King; and then proceeding farther, according to that Power they had, expell'd again≈øt the King's Will ≈øeveral of his chiefe≈øt Favourites from the Court; con≈øtrain'd others to put in Sureties to appear at the next Parliament, and caus'd ≈øeveral others to be arre≈øted and committed to ≈øeveral Pri≈øons. If a Convention could do this where the King was pre≈øent, what ≈øignifi'd the Writs and Concurrence of an
ab≈øent Prince. Nor did they contend for Legi≈ølative Power, but only met in a kind of embodied Dictator≈øhip to take care of the pre≈øent Nece≈ø≈øity of Affairs.

But this, ≈øays the Di≈øcu≈ø≈øer, was not ju≈øtifiable, for that the Nene≈ø≈øity which they pretended, was either of their own making, or of their own ≈øubmitting to, which is the ≈øame Thing. But this is all Non≈øence. For if the Nece≈ø≈øity was of their own making, then were the Lords and Commons the Authors of all the Mi≈øcarriages which they laid to the late King's Charge; If of their own ≈øubmitting to, then would they never have call'd out for ≈øuccour and crav'd Relief from their Oppre≈ø≈øions. No‚ÄîThey were tho≈øe crying Grievances ≈øum'd up in the Declaration of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal and Commons a≈ø≈øembl'd at We≈øtmi≈øter pre≈øented to their Pre≈øent Maje≈øties upon the Twelfth of February La≈øt; which when the late King could not ju≈øtify them by force of Arms, but fled for it, not being able to an≈øwer his endeavours to ≈øubvert and Extirpate the Prote≈øtant Religion and the Laws and Liberties of the Kingdom, put them to that nece≈ø≈øity of a≈ø≈øembling after an Unu≈øual Manner, to provide for the Common Safety.

How ever the Di≈øcu≈ø≈øer will have it a Nece≈ø≈øity of their own creating, tho never ≈øo fal≈øe. For, ≈øays he, if the King had either not bin driven out of his Dominions, or invited back upon honourable Terms, they needed not have had recour≈øe to ≈øuch unu≈øual ≈øingular Methods of proceeding. And thus the Di≈øcu≈ø≈øer rambles out of one Untruth into another. For he fled from offer'd Treaty, for≈øook the defence of his own Forces, and left them to be disbanded in Arrears and without Payment; ≈ølipt from his own Council by Night, after he had appointed to meet them in Con≈øultation the next Morning. Nor could he ju≈øtly ≈øu≈øpect, that any Violence would have been offer'd to Him in particular, being ≈øo well a≈ø≈øur'd as he could not choo≈øe but be, of the Generous Inclination, and profound Re≈øpect which the Prince had to his Per≈øon. But if the Guilt of peculiar Mi≈øcarriages ha≈øten'd his Departure, or over≈øway'd him toleave the He ‚Ä¢ m of Rule without any Form or Face of Goverment: That could ne're be call'd an Expul≈øion out of his Dominions. And therefore when a certain Gentleman waiting on him at Fever≈øham be≈øought him to return to London, he gave the Per≈øon this Reply, That he was an hone≈øt Gentleman, but knew not what he knew. And when he had once abandon'd the Kingdom all forlorn without either Head or Conduct, without Council, or any Countenance of
Authority, then according to the Judgment of the Common-wealth of Venice in reference to the Succe≈ø≈øion of Henry the 4th. it belong'd to the Nobility and chief Per≈øons of the Land, as they are the chief Defence of the Royal Authority, to take care of the Publick Safety, whether by u≈øual or unu≈øual Methods of proceeding it matters not; and they have both the Authority of Law and Nece≈ø≈øity to ju≈øtify their Proceedings.

As for his being invited back upon Honourable Terms, 'tis well known how he return'd back, and went through the City on the Sunday Night, attended by his own Guards, and lodg'd in White-Hall, and this mo≈øt certainly in order to an Accommodation. Only becau≈øe the Prince was coming to Town, he was ≈øent to, and for the avoiding any Di≈øturbance that might be prejudicial to his Per≈øon, was humbly de≈øir'd to retire to Ham-Hou≈øe, with Liberty to make choice of what Per≈øons he thought fit to attend him. Which he promi≈øed to do; but recollecting him≈øelf, and de≈øiring to know whether he might not return back to Roche≈øter, word was ≈øent him the next Morning that he might do as he pleas'd. All this while here was no Con≈øtraint put upon him; ≈øo that he could not be ≈øaid to be driven out of his. Dominions, but that it was his own Choice to for≈øake it.

Notwith≈øtanding all this, The Di≈øcu≈ø≈øer will undertake to prove, That the King before his withdrawing had ≈øufficient Grounds to make him apprehen≈øive of Danger, and therefore it could not be call'd an Abdication.

But through the whole Pur≈øuit of his Argument, the Di≈øcu≈ø≈øer mo≈øt wretchedly mi≈øtakes the Point, quite mi≈øtaking the Effects for the Cau≈øes. For, ≈øays he, Had not the King great Rea≈øon to retire to ≈øecure his Per≈øon and his Honour, when he had met with ≈øo many unfortunate Di≈øappointments, with ≈øo many ≈øurpri≈øing and unparallel'd Accidents? When part of the Army was revolted, and the Remainder too apparently un≈øerviceable; When the People had ≈øuch fatal and unremoveable Prejudices again≈øt his Service? When there were ≈øuch terrible Di≈øorders in the Kingdom, and all Places were either flaming or ready to take Fire? What ≈øhould a Prince do when he had ≈øcarce any thing left him to lo≈øe but him≈øelf, but con≈øult his Safety, and give way to the irre≈øi≈øtable Evil?

The≈øe are very great Di≈øappointments and evil Accidents indeed to befal a Prince. But the Di≈øcu≈ø≈øer forgets to tell ye, That the Prince
brought all the≈øe Inconveniencies upon him≈øelf. The Di≈øcu≈ø≈øer tells ye that part of the Army revolted, but he omits to tell ye, that it was out of a Generous Principle, for that being Prote≈øtants, they would not embrue their Hands in the Blood of their Fellow. Prote≈øtants and Countreymen, nor be In≈øtruments to en≈ølave the Nation. He tells ye of terrible Di≈øorders in the Kingdom; but does not tell ye, it was time for the People to be in Di≈øorder, when they ≈øaw ≈øuch Incroachments upon their Ancient Franchi≈øes, ≈øuch Inundations of Popery flowing in upon their Con≈øciences, and ≈øuch a rapid Violence of French Thraldom tumbling in upon their Necks. He complains that all Places were either flaming or ready to take Fire, but forgets to tell you who were the Incendiaries.

The≈øe therefore, with ≈øeveral others of the ≈øame Nature, being the true Cau≈øes that drew the fore≈øaid Inconveniencies upon the King, it follows, that tho the Secondary Con≈øtraint of his withdrawing might be occa≈øion'd by the Effects, yet the Primary Cau≈øe of his withdrawing proceeded from the Fir≈øt Cau≈øes which produced the Effects. Con≈øequently ≈øuch a Retiring was voluntary and not forc'd; becau≈øe he may be ju≈øtly ≈øaid to fly from ≈øomething of dreaded Puni≈øhment, rather then pur≈øuing Danger, from which he was always at a di≈øtance far enough off, but dubious what would become of him as to the Former.

The Di≈øcu≈ø≈øer makes many other grievous Complaints to ju≈øtify the King's Fir≈øt withdrawing (for hitherto he is altogether upon that) but when he comes to ≈øum up all. In ≈øhort, ≈øays he, when the Forts and Revenue were thus di≈øpo≈øed of; when the Papi≈øts were to be disbanded, and the Prote≈øtants not to be tru≈øted; when the Nation was under ≈øuch general and violent Di≈ø≈øatisfactions; when the King in ca≈øe of a Rupture had nothing upon the matter but his ≈øingle Per≈øon, to oppo≈øe again≈øt the Princes Arms, and tho≈øe of his Subjects; when his Mortal Enemies were to ≈øit Judges of his Crown and Dignity, if no father; when Affairs were in this tempe≈øtuous Condition, to ≈øay that a Free and Indifferent Parliament might be cho≈øen, with the Relation to the King's Right as well as the People's, and that the King had no ju≈øt vi≈øible Cau≈øe to apprehend him≈øelf in Danger, is to out-face the Sun and trample upon the Under≈øtandings, and almo≈øt upon the Sen≈øes of the whole Nation.

As for the Fortified Towns, it was but Rea≈øon that his then Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange, who came over to re≈øcue the Nation
from Arbitrary Violence and Oppre≈ø≈øion, ≈øhould demand them to be put into his Power, well Knowing them to be then in the Hands of Iri≈øh Papi≈øts and Cut-Throats, of whom the People ≈øtood in Perpetual Fear, and who were rather a Con≈øternation then Security to the Kingdom. And the ≈øame rea≈øon holds in Relation to the Revenue. 2. 2. Let it be granted, what ought not to be denied, That the late King did abdicate, and that the Government did devolve upon the People, and the≈øe in a full Repre≈øentative of the whole Nation, whether in Parliament, or in a Convention, (it matters not which, whil≈øt that was a free and fair Choice) have con≈øtituted the≈øe to be our Governours; Are we not to pay and ≈øwear Obedience unto them, as well as their Predece≈ø≈øors? And now, good Sir, be per≈øwaded to lay a≈øide all Prejudice, ≈øubmit your Sentiments to the Judgment of your Superiors, yield your Obedience and Fealty in taking the Oaths; this you ≈øee is your Duty, and not only ≈øo, but your Intere≈øt. THat your Petitioner in the Year 1678, di≈øcovered a horrid Popi≈øh Con≈øpiracy for the De≈øtruction of the late King Charles the Second, His Pre≈øent Maje≈øty, and the Prote≈øtant Religion within the≈øe Kingdoms; and prov'd it ≈øo fully, that ≈øeveral Parliaments, and Courts of Ju≈øtice, before whom he gave his Te≈øtimony, declared their Belief of it by publick Votes, and the Condemnation of ≈øeveral of the Con≈øpirators. After this, the ≈øame Popi≈øh Party obtained leave from King Charles the ≈øecond, to prefer two ≈øeveral Indictments again≈øt your Petitioner, for two pretended Perjuries in his Evidence concerning the ≈øaid Con≈øpiracy, which they brought on to Tryal in the Reign of King James the ≈øecond; and your Petitioner was upon the Evidence of tho≈øe very Witne≈ø≈øes, who had confronted him in three former Tryals, and were disbelieved; and through the Partial Behahaviour of the Chief Ju≈øtice Jeffreys, in brow-beating his Witne≈ø≈øes, and mi≈øleading the Juries, convicted of the ≈øaid Pretended Perjuries, and received this inhumane and unparallel'd Sentence following, viz. [To pay two thou≈øand Marks to the King: To be deve≈øted of his Canonical Habit: To be brought into We≈øtmin≈øter-Hall with a Paper upon his Head, with this In≈øcription, Titus Oates convicted upon full Evidence of two horrid Perjuries: To ≈øtand in and upon the Pillory two ≈øeveral days, for the ≈øpace of an Hour: To be whip'd by the comman Hang-man, from Aldgate to Newgate on Wedne≈øday, and to be whip'd again on the Friday following from Newgate to Tiburn: To ≈øtand in and upon the Pillory five times in every Year of his Life; and to remain a Pri≈øoner during his Life.] Which Sentence being intended, as your Petitioner hath ju≈øt rea≈øon to believe, to murther him, was accordingly executed with all the Circum≈øtances of Barbarity; he having ≈øuffered ≈øome thou≈øands of Stripes whereby he was put to un≈øpeakable Tortures, and lay ten Weeks under the Surgeons Hands. All which illegal Proceedings, and barbarous Inhumanities,

div.head: A SPEECH made by a Member of the Convention of the States in SCOTLAND.
div.p: WE are now called together by his Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange, to Con≈øult and Deliberate, what Methods will be mo≈øt proper to ≈øecure Our Religion, Laws and Liberties, in order to which, the fir≈øt thing that will fall under our Con≈øideration, is the ≈øetling the Sovereign Power.

I take for granted that you are fully convinced, that King James the Seventh, by his many Violations of the Fundamental Laws, by his endeavouring to e≈øtabli≈øh a De≈øpotick and Arbitrary Power, and introduce Popery, (tho he him≈øelf had confirmed all the Laws that were enacted in Favour of the Prote≈øtant Religion) has thereby ≈øubverted the Con≈øtitution, and (that our Mi≈øeries might have no Redre≈øs from him) has left us in a time when we needed his Protection mo≈øt. Burden of it: And it might have been ≈øuppo≈øed that even the≈øe, who had been In≈øtrumental in En≈ølaving their Fellow-Brethren, and were grown Fat with Sucking the Nations Blood, would have taken another Method to Reconcile them≈øelves, than by per≈øuading us to purcha≈øe their Safety, at ≈øo va≈øt an Expence as the Ruin of more than three Parts of the Nation will nece≈ø≈øarily amount to.

If we do but a little reflect on the Motives which the≈øe Men (blinded by Self-Intere≈øt) make u≈øe of, to delude the Nation into a Security that wanted very little of proving Fatal to it, and compare them with the ≈øtrong Rea≈øons, we have to di≈ø≈øwade us from being ≈øo impo≈øed on, they will be found ≈øo Weak and Impertinent, that we mu≈øt judg it next to Impo≈ø≈øibility, to ≈øuffer our ≈øelves to be twice Deceived. But if the Experience of our former Mi≈øeries, ≈øo lately hanging over our Heads, (the very Thoughts of renewing which, make all good Men to tremble) has not made us Wi≈øer, and be not of Efficacy enough, to deter us from venturing another Shipwrack, and expo≈øing all again to the Di≈øcretion of Roman Catholicks: It's more than probable that GOD has abandoned us, and given us up to believe ≈øtrong Delu≈øions.

Fir≈øt, Thay will endeavour to per≈øwade us, that Kings are eximed from Puni≈øhments here on Earth, and nothing they do can be quarrelled by their Subjects, which indeed might with ≈øome Rea≈øon be urged among the Turks, who re≈øerve nothing from the Power of their Sultans, and where it's Death to di≈øpute his Commands, tho never ≈øo Arbitrary and Tyrannical: But with what Impudence can ≈øuch Stuff be impo≈øed on us, who never admit our Kings to the Government, till they ≈øwear to rule us according to Law, and no otherways? The Speculative Doctrine of Pa≈ø≈øive Obedience, has done too much mi≈øchief among us, and what has befallen the King may be ju≈øtly imputed to it, for the believing that without Oppo≈øition he might do what he plea≈øed, encouraged him to take ≈øuch mea≈øures as have drawn all the≈øe Misfortunes on him.

Secondly, Others are ≈øo Fond as to believe, that we may be Secure in calling the King back, provided they ≈øo Limit him, that it will not be in his power to hurt us. The≈øe Men do not con≈øider, how ≈ømall a Complement this is to a Man of the Kings Temper, from ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ an Ab≈øolute Prince, as he was plea≈øed to fancy him≈øelf, to content him≈øelf with the bare Title of a King; and how in≈øupportable the Charge mu≈øt be, if from being Ma≈øter of all, he mu≈øt force him≈øelf to comply with a thou≈øand Ma≈øters, and ≈øee his Throne become his Pri≈øon.
